lg.l: Old Latimer's preaching did fairly describe
A Prelate, that ruled all the rest of the Tribe.
But who was this Bishop? And where did he dwell?
Why surely 'twas Satan ArchBishop of Hell!
For he was a Primat, and he wore a Mitre
Surrounded with Jewels of Sulpher and Nitre.
How nearly his Bishop our Bishops resembles!
But his had the odds who believes and who trembles.
Had you seen his grim face for a pound to a penny
You would swear it must be the Baboon of Kilkenny.Poor Satan will think the comparison odious,
I wish I could find him out one more commodious!
But this I am sure the most Reverend old Dragon
Has got on the Bench many Bishops Suffragan;
And all men believe he presides there in Cog,
To give them by turns an invisible Jog.
The Bishops, puft up with wealth and with pride,
To Hell on the backs of the Clergy would ride.
They mounted, and labour'd with whip and with spur
In vain, for the Devil a Parson would stir:
So the Commons unhorsed them, and this was their Doom
On their Crosiers to ride like the Witch on her Broom
Tho' they gallop so fast on the road you may find 'em.
And have left us but three out of twenty behind 'em.
Lord Bolton's good Grace, Lord Car, and Lord Howard,
In spight of the Devil would still prove untoward;
For they came of good Blood, and could not endure
Their former Companions should beg at the Door.When Christ was betrayed to Pilate the Pretor,
In a dozen Apostles but one proved a Traytor;
One Traytor alone, and faithful eleven;
But we can afford you six Traytors in seven.
What a cluter with cleanings, dividings, and cleavings?
And the Clergy forsooth must take up with their leavings
If making divisions was all their intent
They've done it we thank 'em──but not as they meant:
And so may such Bishops for ever divide;
That no honest Heathen would be of their side.
How should we rejoyce if, like Judas the first,
These Splitters of Parsons in sunder would burst.Now hear an Allusion; The Mitre you know
Is divided above but united below:
If this you consider, my Emblem is right
For the Bishops divide but the Clergy unite:
If the bottom should burst those Prelates may dread
That the Mitre would never stick fast on their head:
And yet they have learned the chief art of a Sovreign,
As Matchiaval taught 'em, Divide and you'l govern.But courage my Lords, tho' it cannot be said
That one cloven tongue ever sat on your head;
Yet I'd hold you a groat, and I wish I could see't,
If your stockens were off, you could shew cloven feet.But hold cry the Bishops, pray give us fair play──
Before you condemn us hear what we can say.
What truer affection could ever be shewn
Than saving your souls by damning our own?
And have we not practis'd all methods to gain you?
With the Tythe of the Tythe of the Tythe to maintain you:
Provided a Fund for building your Spitals?
You are only to live four years without Victuals──
It is true my good Lords.──But let us change hands──
First take you our Tythes, and give us your Lands.
Then God bless the Church, and three of the Mitres
And God bless the Commons for Biting the Biters803-001C
